div.p: ANTONIO: So, we've already talked a lot about impairment problems. But what we really want to know is how to prevent them.
ANTONIO: And you've already got the formula for that. First, biology sets our level of risk for impairment problems, largely through our tolerance level.
ANTONIO: The second part of the equation is our choices. We know the low-risk guidelines—0,1,2,3—will help us to prevent both health problems and impairment problems.
ANTONIO: When it comes to our choices, we've got to keep our eye on the ball, so to speak. Because if we get distracted by our surroundings or our beliefs...
ANTONIO: Well it doesn't take a genius to figure out what's going to happen next.
ANTONIO: For example, if we start to think alcoholism is a result of the type of person we are, we're not keeping our eye on the ball—our choices—and that's where our focus needs to be.
ANTONIO: It's the same with impairment problems. Some beliefs, like thinking impairment problems are "just bad luck," can distract us from staying focused on our choices.
